newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria won't be pushed on privatisation.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria won't be pushed on privatisation.

text.p: Nigeria will privatise its state enterprises at its own pace despite pressure from home and abroad to move more quickly, finance minister Anthony Ani said on Monday.

"We have not said we are not going to privatise, what we are saying is that a committee will look into the issue more carefully," Anthony Ani told a news conference following his detailed breakdown of the 1997 budget.
Military ruler General Sani Abacha, in a nationwide radio and television broadcast on Saturday, said government needed more consultations before embarking on privatisation of state companies.

Disappointment spread through much of Nigeria's financial community, which had expected a commitment to rapid privatisation of companies in sectors such as oil production, refining, telecommunications and power generation.
The World Bank and local business leaders had been pressing for privatisation, saying it would bring in badly needed funds to stimulate economic growth.
Oil-rich Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, has been in recession since 1993 when the country slid into crisis over annulment of an election that would have restored democracy.
"We do not want to rush into privatisation and it is not a matter of not having the political will...no one anywhere can tell us what we should do," said Ani.

The government has also been criticised for keeping a dual exchange rate system which allows it to buy foreign exchange at a rate of 22 naira to the dollar instead of the market rate of 80 naira to the dollar.
"We will look at the social impact of a merger (of the exchange rates) and allow the government time to look into all the ramifications of the issue," Ani said.
He said the government would target growth at 5.5 percent in 1997, up from 3.25 percent in 1996.
Measures proposed for stimulating growth include putting money into agriculture and food production, family economic development and exploitation of minerals other than crude oil.
Abacha's tight fiscal and monetary policies through 1995 and 1996 have not stimulated growth, but have brought annual inflation from above 80 percent to below 30 percent.
Ani said tight monetary policy would continue through 1997, with the aim of bringing inflation as low as 15 percent.
